title: Welcome

introducer: John Breslin, DERI Galway, National University of Ireland, Galway

segmentation: OK, good morning everyone and welcome to ICO Sam.
The 6th International Aaar Conference on Weblogs and social media.
I'd like to welcome you all to Dublin Gardens for what promises to be a very exciting conference.
As you know, this is the latest in the ISA WSM series of conferences where we are bringing together an computing in social science research into social media.

Time is now in a six year and in an effort to maintain its strong interdisciplinary flavor, we've brought together what I believe is a very strong program of invited talks, presentations and posters and demos.
So we've already had a fascinating day yesterday.
Who's at the workshops inventories yesterday ends up Grace.
Yeah well.
We have a very interesting talks during the workshops and some great tutorials and I'm delighted general Chairman to be able to kick off the rest of this event.
We've also had a record number of registrations this year, so we are up by about 25% to 330.
Last year we did about 265% to 75275, so that's good news for the conference.
OK, so before.
Get stars I wanted to thank our sponsors.
We had a Grace Grace sponsorship drive this year and we were very lucky to have a greater range of sponsors so our platinum sponsor is Science Foundation, Ireland or SFI we had.
Other sponsors Google, Bing and Microsoft Research Meeting Orleans, which is from Fulcher Islands, are tourism boards talk.
And we have bronze sponsors Yahoo Research, Deja Nescio Noesis at Wright State University, IBM and Church, and Duncan Group.
So appreciate your thanks to our sponsors for helping us to make this happen today.
So one of the good features of our sponsorship was that we managed to double the number of travel grants we gave out this year, so it was good news.
I think for the student community and then we actually managed to give out twice a number of friends.
So thanks again to respond to fresh.
I'd also like to take video lectures.
We have made us here today from video lectures dot Nash for the videos will be posted after the conference.

Haven't figured out already and you can return those to AETOS.
Also you need to give a copy of your slides on a USB stick to which they will also has to us and.
You could identify all our volunteers by the way they all have.
I see there was some T shirts on, so if you need any help during the conference, feel free to seek the mesh.
OK.
So.
Organizing conferences year long commitments commitments.

As I found out from the conference committee from JPC members and also from our colleagues in Tripoli, I I'd like to adknowledge the team who brought this conference together and I will ask you again to give your tanks to.
Then maybe after I've called us all of the names.
So AAA eyes.

Carol Hamilton, the executive director, and Karina Lens out of an for all the reference thank them for their dedication in making ice is that I see this happen this year and every year did a great job and I know many of you have been in touch with them by email throughout the year and put it put a face to the emails.
Secondly, our local organizers Connor Hayes and from Darien anyway, and Eric Green were up here in the middle.
They directly from UCD, they managed to secure this fantastic venue.
So we had a bit of a crisis a few weeks ago.
As many conferences do in terms of venue, we had to move building a short notice and thanks to Derek and Connor for helping us to get things running on the ground here.

Derek Ruths from McGill and in Sabra from IST.
Who's here are data shares an Alex James from Yahoo?
Who was our demos chair, Max Wilson from Nottingham.
Who's our social media chair?

Bernie Hogan from the Oxford Internet Institute, who is our tutorials chair's OfficeMax, Cassie, from Isi's USC, who was our workshop chair Sheila Kinsella from data who's our industry chair, which is a new role this year for our industry events, which I'll talk about in a few minutes.
And British Agrawal who is our Webmaster from AT&T.
We also.

So from.

We had a pretty intense but very successful program chairs meeting in DC and February wasn't it?
And I think we really kind of gone well together and I want to thank Department chairs for their dedication to making this program happen this year.
So we have pretty, I think a very strong but also very diverse program this year.
OK.
So as one of our technical program we have really great selection of Keynote, invited speakers, invited panelists.
As you'll see on Wednesday.
Yeah, on Wednesday afternoon we have this industry events.
Now we've had panel sessions in the past as I see them, but this year we decided to have a more.
Broad industry events where we could basically allow Members who are those people who are interested in social media.
People who are partitioners social media, choose yes to interact with the technical participants in conference.
So this year we have a social story, a social media industry event on Wednesday, and we're going to have an injury keynote into industry panels.
The first industry panel is on social business and the 2nd is Japan's on social news.
So I think also the keynote talks we have today, tomorrow and Thursday reflects the balance between offline and online networks.
Offline and.
So we're social offline and we're social online.

So after our welcome session we will have Andrew Tompkins here from Google Plus who will talk talk us through the offline human social networking history and how it relates to the future of online social networking and specifically talk about Google Plus and how how it relates to that.
Tomorrow we have a larger Adams who is going to speak to us as you know ladders.
A serial ICWSN best paper award winner, and she's going to talk to us about the information life of social.
On Wednesday, as part of the industry events, Igor Perisic from LinkedIn is going to talk us through some dynamics of social networking and following the jobs ecosystem.
And then in terms they were going to have Robin Dunbar, who you may know from the term dunbars number.
He's the anthropology professor at the University of Oxford and his keynote talk is entitled to why Facebook won't get you anymore friends.
So also enters a.
We've invited for Brazil's sestini from its tail is from the European Commission.

He heads up the future Internet research Area and also the Internet science areas, and he's going to give us a talk which is titled collective awareness platforms for Sustainability and Social Innovation.
And as I mentioned, we're going to grace discussion panels on on on Wednesday afternoon.
Very distinguished guests from the worlds of business and media.
OK, so I also want to give you kind of a taster of some of the papers from the technical problems are coming up and I'm just kind of selected a random selection that matched up with my Lego kits.
So I'm going to give you a taste of summer.

Posters are full on talks, an liking talks, the Lightning talks just to remind you they consist of a one minute poster presentation which will be followed by a poster session and post session will be held outside the theater here at the back of the theater and that's open space outside the lighting.
The presentations will have their posters.
That's called the Bull nose area, so we hear people talking about the bull nose area.
It's just just outside there.
OK, so one of the papers to be presented this afternoon is this one, which is talking about the livelihoods project, and it's an effort to use social media to understand the dynamics of a city.
Later on today, we're going to hear about gaming Guilds in the multiplayer online game World of Warcraft, and we're going to find out how group dynamics can be modeled in this game.
Also today the paper, which is the great title.
People are strange when you're a stranger, will discuss how bots can be perceived to have positive characteristics when they're deployed in social networks.
Can the spread of disease be models and correlated using social social interactions online paper this afternoon will discuss this.
In the poster sessions evening.
There is going to be a paper which use uses a supervised approach to predict Co acquisition using profiles obtained from the technology website TechCrunch and also from its.
Company database crunchbase.
Another great title, tweeting in the rain at the same post assertion will talk about how online mood changes can be gauged in line with various weather shifts.
And tomorrow we're going to hear from Georgia Tech.
They're going to ask us if we've heard about how gossip flows through email networks in.
Enterprise.
We're going to paper, which is going to look at the daily patterns of people's lives and their routines and how they can be studied and measured using activities updated online.
And on Thursday, we're going to.
Propose grassroots professional development in the classroom and how educators are using microblogging in the classroom.
And finally, also on Thursday.
Again, this is just kind of a random selection and we're going to hear about paper called hiding in plain sight, which is about trust and mistrust in a community of citizen reporters.
OK, so.
Kind of a selection of some of our our our papers during the next few days, so we've had a greater sporting week in Dublin.

You're on your own for lunch Bush.

Jerry Maddock, who is the man who designed the Apple Macintosh?
He's going to speak as a free event that's being held in the science category.
So if your Macintosh fan, you may be interested in going to that.
It's outside of the conference button.
It's website is here so you can pre register for dash at sciencegallery.com.
We're going to follow this up with a informal drinks meet up on Thursday evening at 8:00 PM in O'Neill's pub on Suffolk St, which is near here as well.
OK, so I hope you have a great time in Dublin and who knows, maybe we won't stay here forever and ever and ever and please join.

I see them.
Hope you have a productive and enjoyable conference.
